item.title: Goal: Read 1000 (Children's) Books in 2018
item.description: Introduction Over Christmas 2017, my wife, Jill, resolved that our family (to include babysitters) would read our children over 1000 new books in 2018. More specifically, 29 December 2017 - 28 December 2018. A goal like this takes dedication, love, and of course, a Data Science-y approach. Special thanks to Ally, Zia, and Bookbuddy for help in accomplishing this goal! Also, special thanks to drob and juliasilge who privde the tidytext package and the entire R open-source community I rely on to do this analysis.

item.title: Working with Dates in R
item.description: A Little About Dates in R Before we launch into any analysis that contains dates, we should know a few important nuggets about how R handles date-like objects. There are 3 date/time classes are built in to R - Date - POSIXct - POSIXlt Base R First, base R can read a string of text and convert it to a date class. To help it read the date, you must tell R what date format your character string should expect.

item.title: Helping A Colleague Explore Data
item.description: Introduction A colleague of mine asked me to help him explore a dataset in R. He has little experience in R, so I will provide as much detail as I can in this exploration. My goal here is to make this post both ‘learn-able’ and ‘replicable’. Install and/or load necessary packages if (!require("tidyverse")) install.packages("tidyverse") if (!require("readr")) install.packages("readr") if (!require("lubridate")) install.packages("lubridate") if (!require("stringi")) install.packages("stringi") Set Working Directory If Necessary # setwd("//filepath/of/your/csvfile") Read in data We use read_csv from the readr package because it does a better job than the base read.
